review_title: Great people, great mission, but the reality of the work may come as a surprise
pros:
- The people: Both in terms of the staff just being fun people to hang out with, and their commitment to the mission. Everyone is passionate about a country, region, or international relations in general, otherwise they wouldn't be there.
- Travel: Even Program Associates typically have the opportunity to travel once or twice a year
- Leadership: I worked in the Middle East and North Africa division and really loved my deputy and regional director. They were equally invested in the programs themselves and their staff's professional development. I also found them to be great listeners, fair, and direct.
cons:
- This is an administrative job that requires no knowledge of the region, no language skills, and no creativity. It is easy to get jaded because most people who work there do so because they genuinely want to make a difference in the world, but the reality is that you are doing the behind-the-scenes work that makes the in-country work possible (processing contracts and payments, writing quarterly reports, overseeing the budget, etc.), so it's not interesting, and it is easy to feel disconnected. 
- You also see a lot of money being wasted which can be disheartening
- The pay is no good, and even with many promotions, you're still not going to be making decent money
- I can't speak for what the culture is like now, but when I was there, everyone complained constantly, and I think people fed off of one another. It was a pretty negative work environment

review_title: Lucky to be Part of IRI
pros:
Are the hours long?
Yes.

Do the days sometimes blend together because you are overseas and are getting little to no sleep? 
Yes. 

Do you want to scream because you can not figure out why your reconciliation keeps getting rejected? 
At least once a month. 

Is it worth it?
Yes. Every second of it is worth it. 

The work IRI does is topnotch. At times we forget how important it is because we get bogged down with paperwork and procurement. But, every day this place moves the needle. And, that is why we stay. 

As cheesy as it sounds, this place is like a large family. We disagree... often. We get annoyed with each other. But, when it comes down to it, we are always there for each other. 

Let me give you some examples:

A young girl's boyfriend passed away unexpectedly. Berevement policy states that paid time off is only for the death of next of kin. IRI gave her paid time off anyways.  A young man had a severe medical problem and used all his sick time. Staff donated time and did routine check-ups on him. When people travel other staff watches their pets, check in on their homes, and even pick up their kids from school.

IRI has 200 people in DC. And no matter what division they work for or what they do at IRI, they are part of this patchwork crew that leaves no one behind.
cons: If you do not want to put in 9 to10 hour days on a consistent basis, this place is not for you.

pros: Teamwork, Good Systems, Accountability, Commitment
cons: Small teams, Long Procedures, Turnover of Staff, Stringent rules

review_title: Came In With High Hopes, Left Completely Frustrated
pros: For those doing direct program work in foreign countries, the experience is unique and gives plenty of exposure to the needs that drive democracy and governance development. For those doing the backstopping, you know you have better office digs than those in the field.
cons:
This is an organization that focuses neither on merit nor innovation, and the result is staid programming and a frustrating work life. There is never a sense of urgency. There is never a drive to try something new to solve a problem. There is no effort to understand what motivates people to do well. The mediocre pay and benefits can't compensate.

I completely agree with the previous reviewer's assessment that patronage and cronyism dominates hiring and advancement. On the regional director level, it can descend to high-school-drama-like antics if an underling wants to transfer to a different division and the two directors don't like each other. No question preference is given to those who dare not question the inefficiency or ineffectiveness of programming or people. As a result, there are a good number of directors on various levels whose questionable competencies nicely complement their bottled-up frustrations.

review_title: Great place to work doing valuable work
pros: The people that work here are serious, committed, smart and fun to work with. The work remains some of the most interesting out there for those interested in democracy and governance, with some really innovative and novel programming across the globe. The work culture is pretty informal and collaborative. There are a number of reforms undertaken to improve the running and effectiveness of the organization that have really transformed the place into more of a learning organization and in many ways IRI is ahead of its competitors in this respect. Its a great place to learn and share your experience and expertise doing some really valuable, mission-driven work around the world.The benefits are also some of the best in the non-profit sector.
cons: There remains the same levels of bureaucracy as at many non-profits but still there could be improvements in making processes more efficient and accessible. Managing knowledge still remains a challenge as people move between and out of positions. There are of course remain some folks who are more interested in control than empowerment at the middle management level. Figuring out ways to incentivize team members to reward many of the efforts that are often not included in formal reviews, such as the Institute's Communities of Practice, also remains an area of weakness.

review_title: Great career opportunity, but horrible management that lack business/professional understanding
pros: Offers a great opportunity for the right person who wants to work on political party/civil society overseas  programming.  The organization is designed to give great exposure to grant management to entry level positions that includes proposal writing, budgeting, and donor outreach.  There are still some great people at IRI and if you are lucky to work for one you will learn a lot.
cons: The organization is a bureaucracy, four or more people usually need to sign off on something as simple as a tweet (which you are not sending yourself).  The frustrations of constant micromanagement can turn a great employee, which is unfortunate because some of the junior staff are dedicated to the mission.  Because the organization has a global reach there are many times that the employee will be asked to work long hours and correspond with foreign offices at unusual times (with no overtime or comp-time).  Additionally, the organization is very sensitive to audits which has a negative impact on staff and IRI's accounting department; so for those not detailed oriented or don't like writing cya memos this is not a place for you to work.

pros: They provide a 10% retirement contribution

pros: The idea of working to advance freedom, equality, and equal representation worldwide is wonderful.  For those who are mission driven, the IDEA of the work is really wonderful.
cons: This organization is a perfect paradigm for "what not to do." Between a total lack of management, absence of business know-how, pervasive bureaucracy, absolute black hole of office culture and dead-end reality of career advancement,  I can say my most valuable skills gained included how to handle crises and how to manage up.  The opportunities to travel or perform rewarding work are overshadowed and tainted completely by everything else that comes with working at IRI.  The people who work there come in talented, sharp, interested, and interesting; after a period of time they are not only unhappy, but the culture is so that one is made to feel pretty worthless, and unskilled despite their talents and strong capabilities.  I think this place could have been /can be  great, but it's a LONG road there.

review_title: Good for Beginners, Bad for Experienced Professionals
job_title: Senior Program Associate in Washington, DC
pros:
If you are starting as an entry level  junior staffer (Program Associate) or are a recent graduate, you will get the opportunity to take on a lot of large projects and work on big programs (largely because there is always more work to do than there are people to do it). The benefit is you may get the chance to travel frequently, organize conferences and draft proposals early in your career, thereby gaining valuable work experience. IRI is also a very supportive place to learn the ropes.  Good for a newcomers, but if you have more experience and are looking for some independence and decision-making power in a Program Officer position or above, look somewhere else. 

Second, if you loved the high school social scene, then you'll fit right in. While there are a lot of really great, kind people, there are also a lot of gossipers and unprofessional workplace relationships. On the plus side, IRI does feel like a family in that aspect and leaving IRI feels like you're leaving the comfort of your "home." For that reason, many people stay for decades on end.
cons:
There is a huge lack of transparency from the senior staff to the junior staff level (which is ironic for a democracy promotion and good governance NGO). Many decisions are made by the senior staff without input from junior staff (or even announced to junior staff) despite the fact that these decisions disproportionately affect junior staff. Biggest con is that there is NO UPWARD MOBILITY or promotions based on merit. If you start as an SPA, don't expect to be promoted until you've  been there at least 1.5 years (2 yrs is more likely), regardless of your performance or the work you are actually doing. It is very common for Program Associates to be doing the work of a Program Officer, while being paid significantly less. Part of this comes with the territory of working in a non-profit organization where its all hands on deck all the time or funding may not be there at the time you are asking for a promotion. In actuality though, these reasons are used by Directors as an excuse not to promote people so they can keep salaries low in case the grant is overspent or there is a lack of funding down the line. Therefore, there is high staff turnover at significant cost to the institute. The pay is also abysmal unless you are an expat and receive post-diff and a housing allowance. IRI does not seem to  value compensating employees based on their contributions to the company. Also, annual increases are 3% for a job well done, up to 6% if they feel guilty about underpaying you so much to begin with. Almost no one is fired for poor performance (another huge issue).

Finally, the work culture needs improvement. IRI is extremely cliquey, everyone gossips about each other, dates each other, and there is general antagonism between the expats and DC staff.  Poor management at the divisional-level also means that many expats abuse their DC staffers and visa versa.

pros: The staff at IRI are dedicated democracy assistance professionals who work hard to advance one of the most important missions facing the world today. Great travel opportunities and chances to design and implement programs that make real progress advancing democracy and providing support to democracy activists around the world.
cons: Like any large organizations, IRI has its share of bureaucratic hurdles  and challenges with procurement.

review_title: Good people, but poor management, bureaucracy
pros: There are some really great people here working in the overseas office and on program staff who care about their work and are dedicated to the cause.  Opportunities to interact with important political figures from around the world is a positive, and you will learn a lot about the countries/regions you are working on.  Travel opportunities, depending on your division and position.
cons: Front office management has long been poor.  The president was forced out several years ago but vps and other upper-level figures stayed, so not much has changed despite the new president.  Front office doesn't trust lower level staff, monitors them closely and insert themselves/interfere with processes and decision making that should be left to regional directors.  The front office is always issuing new rules, burdensome approval processes and paperwork requirements that strangles programming and takes up time for program staff that would better be spent doing other things.  There is always more, and it is ALWAYS worse.  Salaries are not competitive compared to other organizations doing similar work, and raises/promotions are more linked to which division you are in, or being "a favorite" of the front office than actual performance.  This is a big problem at IRI that results in a lot of unhappiness among program staff.  It is therefore not a surprise that staff turnover here is so much higher than at other similar organizations.  This MUST be fixed if they want to retain talent.

pros: Shawn, the CIO of the company runs a great shop. The team he assembled is very knowledgeable and have built an environment that is conducive to learning. Coming in as someone with little background in the information technology field, this was extremely helpful. Although it was difficult at times like all roles, the team and management made working at IRI very rewarding and enjoyable.
cons: Wish the internship was longer, was absorbing a lot of information and felt like it was cut short. But took back a plethora of knowledge to school  the following semester.

job_title: Help Desk Level I in Washington, DC

review_title: Great environment, dedicated co-workers, and surprisingly high research autonomy.
pros: First serving as a research intern and then being retained as a research assistant, I was surprised by the breadth of research projects that I am able to pursue with a great deal of autonomy. IRI encourages innovative projects and supports dynamic research. The cooperative environment at IRI supports this greatly. As an organization, IRI is highly innovative and is current management strive to make an impact in the countries the organization works in.
cons: The tea and coffee selections could be improved. No real negatives at this point.

pros: At least some reviews of IRI are, judging from job titles, from people on their first job.  Straight out of college, no job is satisfying -- you're ready to set the world on fire and have all the answers, including on how to run your company.  My first post-college job was with IRI, and after what I thought was a decent experience I left for what I thought would be something better.  Very unstatisfied, I left that second job for a third.  Both paid more but neither measured up to IRI, so I asked to return to IRI and was welcomed back.  I'm one of about 30 people who have had a similar career track, returning to IRI after departing for what we thought would be better jobs.  There's a lot of room for creativity, and opportunity for travel and meaningful work, if you really know your topic.  There's a young and by and large creative and talented staff and a high premium on teamwork.  And a "front office" management that, while not sitting down each and every day with each employee, does care about our welfare.  Standards are high, but if you're very talented, you do get noticed, given additional outside training and promoted --to a point, see cons below; if someone obviously isn't making the grade, including occasionally at the director level, their departure is handled quietly and decently (again, unlike some other places I've worked).  Finally, I don't know many other non-profits that care enough to have a grad school tuition payback program, which obviously helps the company retain employees, but also is a great benefit to those carrying big debt; some of my colleagues are taking grad school at night, with allowances made by management, because of this program.  IRI isn't perfect -- for example the pay is not great -- but it's by far the best place I've worked so far.
cons: The work is meaningful and satisfying, and the benefits good, but the pay is not.  Because many in senior management have been at IRI for years (some rising from internship and entry level positions) there's only so much room for advancement at the top.   Finally, the "front office" does have sporadic lunches with employees including interns, but they should be more frequent.

job_title: Senior Program Associate in Washington, DC
pros: There are some really passionate, incredibly motivated and talented people that work at IRI. I was constantly impressed by the ideas and dedication exhibited by some of my colleagues there. I was also given incredible access to high level political leaders from around the globe, decision makers in Washington, DC and leading intellectuals in development and politics. Because the whole place is wildly understaffed, I could take initiative and was able to get experience in areas that would have been off limits to me anywhere else. The trial-by-fire methodology (or culture?) that exists here makes sure that you will learn a lot in a little time.
cons: Extremely political - skirting (and often crossing) the boundaries of their 501c3 obligations. Constant in-fighting within organizational leadership and front office that trickles down to lower level employees.Makes for an extremely awkward working environment. Lower level and mid-level employees are often burdened with unreasonable work expectations due to extremely poor management (or complete lack thereof) from often incompetent divisional leadership. Those who run divisions seem to be there simply from having stuck with the organization for a couple of decades, not having to prove themselves anywhere else. Nobody here - in a leadership position - understands basic project management. They are still stuck in a 1980's political party/buddy-buddy mentality that the development world moved away from 20 years ago. Leadership often pushes the envelope on corruption by wasting tons of US and Canadian taxpayer money on lavish, unnecessary travel to the detriment of any practical programming. The pay is also a joke - I was paid 40% below my market value here after a promotion and "salary realignment." The benefits no longer make up for this substantial gap - a meagre metro credit doesn't equal hard cash! HR is completely hands off and is forced to do rather unethical things by front office leadership. It is no surprise that turnover in the junior staff here is off the charts - especially at the 2 year mark. Also, there is absolutely NO on-boarding or structured training at this place. If you don't have a colleague to take you under their wing for three months - good luck!

review_title: Going in the wrong direction.  Rapidly.
pros: When I was first hired I enjoyed gaining experience managing projects overseas and the opportunity to interact with foreign dignitaries.  The mission is important, and the projects themselves are interesting and you get a sense of meaning.  Additionally, you are able to become an expert on the politics of particular regions or countries.  There are a lot of dedicated and great people working there, in the field, in the divisional leadership and at the program staff level.
cons:
Rigid hierarchy and centralized structure with a constant barrage of new rules, requirements and burdensome and unnecessary approvals processes coming from the front office.  Over the years, IRI has taken the needless bureaucracy to an astounding and ridiculous level causing many longtime employees to flee in frustration.  It is funny hearing the reactions of new hires who have come from other organizations because the bureaucratic hassles here are unparalleled in both volume and absurdity.  Consider yourself warned.

Over the past almost decade, I have watched in horror as decision-making power has gradually been removed from program officers and replaced with elaborate approval processes for almost everything.  Even simple tasks such as counting how many international trips are available in your own program budget are now subject to higher level approvals!  This is mind-numbingly frustrating as you just can’t get things done yourself - you must take multiple steps and often involve multiple people.  Between the approval processes and silly internal accounting procedures, be prepared to waste significant time printing hundreds of pages of unnecessary paperwork, filling out accounting forms and nagging the many people you are waiting on for approvals to move forward.  

The biggest deadweight here is the front office staff – who exhibit a pernicious need to have a say in all decisions and an alarming disregard for timeliness or honoring our commitments to partners.  Multiple bottlenecks in the approval process and a lack of urgency at the senior staff level means delayed payments, polls sometimes released months after the data was collected and an overall pall of uncertainty over programming.  Some recent front office decisions regarding how we treat contractors and local staff have been so shockingly inept, shortsighted and absolutely unacceptable to me as a person that I felt no choice but to leave.    

I would advise anyone considering working here to be sure to read the reviews below - the descriptions of the cronyism, promotions based on front office whim instead of merit, and treating program staff like untrustworthy children are highly accurate.  This is not a way to attract or retain talent, and one of the plethora of reasons that many of the enthusiastic and gifted people I have worked with over the years have been driven away.  Walk around the cubicle area and notice that many people are actively perusing jobseeker sites.
